## Summary: Christie's Press Release – Leonardo da Vinci's *Salvator Mundi* (October 10, 2017)

### Key Facts
- **Auction house:** Christie's
- **Work:** *Salvator Mundi* by Leonardo da Vinci, an oil on panel painting (~1500), depicting Christ as Savior of the World
- **Sale event:** Christie's Evening Sale of Post-War and Contemporary Art, **November 15, 2017**, Rockefeller Plaza, New York
- **Pre-sale estimate:** "In the region of **$100 million US**" *(note: estimate excludes buyer's premium)*
- The painting is described as one of fewer than **20 known works by Leonardo**, and the **only one in private hands** at the time
- It was rediscovered in **2005**, purchased from a small regional American auction house, after having sold at Sotheby's in **1958 for £45**

### Provenance Highlights
- Previously in the Royal Collection of **King Charles I** and later **Charles II**
- Sold in 1763, then acquired in 1900 as a work by Bernardino Luini (a Leonardo follower)
- Authenticity confirmed after **six years of research** following its 2005 rediscovery

### Named Source Opinions
- **Loic Gouzer** (Chairman, Post-War & Contemporary Art, Christie's): Called it "a painting of the most iconic figure in the world by the most important artist of all time"
- **Alan Wintermute** (Senior Specialist, Old Master Paintings, Christie's): Called it "the Holy Grail of old master paintings" and described its appearance at auction as "an Art World Miracle"

### Relevance to Forecast Question
This article is a **pre-sale announcement** from October 2017, not a results announcement. It establishes that Christie's was offering a painting with an estimate at or above $100 million, but does **not confirm a final sale price**.
</Summary>

## Summary: Leonardo's *Salvator Mundi* Heads to Christie's New York (November 2017)

### Key Facts
- **The work**: *Salvator Mundi* (c. 1500), attributed to Leonardo da Vinci, depicting Christ as "Saviour of the World"
- **Auction**: Christie's New York, **November 15, 2017**, placed within the evening post-war and contemporary sale (with its own separate catalogue)
- **Estimate**: Christie's gave an estimate of **"in the region of $100 million"**
- **Guarantee**: The painting has a **third-party guarantee**, meaning it will sell at or above the estimate regardless of other bidding
- **Seller**: Russian oligarch **Dmitry Rybolovlev**, who purchased it for **$127.5 million in 2013** from Swiss art adviser **Yves Bouvier** (who had acquired it for ~$80 million); legal proceedings between the two are ongoing

### Historical Price Journey
| Year | Event | Price |
|------|-------|-------|
| 1958 | Sold at Sotheby's London (attributed to Boltraffio copy) | **£45** |
| ~2005 | Sold at small regional U.S. auction | **<$10,000** |
| 2013 | Sold to Rybolovlev | **$127.5 million** |
| 2017 | Christie's estimate | **~$100 million** |

### Attribution & Condition
- Accepted as a genuine Leonardo by **most specialists**, including **Nicholas Penny** (former director of the National Gallery, London), who told *The Art Newspaper* he is **"convinced"** it is by Leonardo
- Notable dissent from **Carmen Bambach** (Metropolitan Museum of Art), who believes "much of the painting may have been done by Giovanni Boltraffio, with passages by Leonardo"
- Supporting evidence includes preparatory drawings in the Royal Collection, a 1650 Hollar etching, pigment analysis, and pentimenti
- Condition issues: **serious vertical crack** on the left side; face was **overcleaned**, possibly in the early 17th century; key elements (blessing hand, orb, hair) described as "remarkably intact" by Christie's

### Market Context
- Would **far exceed** the Old Master auction record at the time (Rubens's *Massacre of the Innocents*, sold for **£49.5 million in 2002**)
- Christie's placed it in a contemporary sale to **attract new collectors** beyond traditional Old Master buyers
- Pre-sale tour included **Hong Kong, San Francisco, London, and New York**, suggesting anticipated East Asian interest
- The Dallas Museum of Art reportedly came close to purchasing it in 2012 for up to **$100 million**
</Summary>

## Summary: Leonardo da Vinci's *Salvator Mundi* Sells for $450.3M at Christie's (November 2017)

### Key Facts
- **Sale:** Christie's New York, November 15, 2017
- **Work:** *Salvator Mundi* (~1500), attributed to Leonardo da Vinci, depicting Christ holding a crystal orb
- **Final Price:** **$450.3 million** (including buyer's premium), with a hammer price of **$400 million** — a world record for any work of art sold at auction
- **Seller (consignor):** Russian oligarch **Dmitry Rybolovlev**, who had acquired the work for $127 million through dealer Yves Bouvier
- **Buyer:** Identity not disclosed by Christie's, including region of origin
- **Bidding:** ~20 minutes of telephone bidding; at peak, up to six bidders were competing; notable jumps of $20–30M at a time

### Context & Background
- The painting was placed in Christie's **postwar and contemporary evening sale**, alongside works by Twombly, Basquiat, and Haring
- Christie's secured the work with a **$100 million guarantee**
- Pre-sale tour drew **27,000 viewers** across Hong Kong, London, and San Francisco
- The sale surpassed the previous auction record held by Picasso's *Women of Algiers (Version O)* at $179.4M

### Notable Quotes (Named Sources)
- **Auctioneer Jussi Pylkkänen:** "It's the zenith of my career as an auctioneer. There'll never be another painting that I shall sell for more than this painting tonight."
- **Christie's CEO Guillaume Cerutti:** Confirmed the unusual large bidding jumps reflected bidders' awareness the price would go higher
- **Christie's specialist Alan Wintermute:** Called it the "holy grail" of old masters; affirmed broad scholarly acceptance of its authenticity
- **London dealer Philip Mould:** Called placing it in a contemporary sale "inspired," noting contemporary art is "where all the big money is"

### Other $100M+ Auction Records Referenced in Article
| Work | Sale Price |
|---|---|
| Munch's *The Scream* | $119.9M |
| Picasso's *Nude, Green Leaves and Bust* | $106.5M |
| Giacometti's *L'homme qui Marche I* | ~$105.2M |
| Picasso's *Boy With a Pipe* | $104.2M |

---
*This article is from 2017 and documents a historical sale; it does not contain forward-looking information relevant to the resolution window of the forecast question.*
</Summary>

- The French **Alzheimer's Research Foundation** is raffling Picasso's **1941 portrait *Tête de femme***, valued at over **€1 million**, for **€100 per ticket** in a project called *"1 Picasso for 100 Euros."*
- The draw is scheduled to take place at **Christie's auction house in Paris on April 14** (year not explicitly stated, but contextually 2026).

- The article notes, as background, that Picasso's work "consistently ranks among the world's most expensive art, with **paintings fetching more than $100M at auction**" — though this is a general reference, not a specific recent sale.
- This raffle is **not a public auction sale**; it is a charity raffle, and therefore would **not** qualify under the resolution criteria.

**Long-Lost Rembrandt Prints Resurface After a Century in Storage**
Thirty-five rare etchings by Rembrandt van Rijn, hidden in a family safe for nearly a century, have been rediscovered in the Netherlands. The prints, acquired in the early 20th century by Charlotte Meyer’s grandfather, were examined during the 2020 pandemic by experts from the Rembrandt House Museum in Amsterdam, who confirmed their exceptional condition and significant art historical value. Meyer described the experts as 'completely blow away' by the discovery. The prints, once considered unremarkable due to low interest in etchings at the time, are now believed to be highly valuable—evidenced by recent record sales, including Rembrandt’s 1656 work Arnout Tholinx, which sold for £3.1 million ($4.1 million) at Christie’s London, and a chalk study that fetched nearly $18 million at Sotheby’s New York. The prints will be featured in the exhibition 'Rembrandt: From Dark to Light' at the Stedelijk Museum Zutphen, running from March 21 to June 14, 2026. The exhibition will include over 70 works by Rembrandt’s predecessors and followers, pieces from Meyer’s expanded collection, an interactive display on etching techniques, and a multi-sensory experience evoking 17th-century Amsterdam.

**Two Paths to Rare Art: Auctions and Private Sales in the Global Collecting Landscape**
The article outlines two primary pathways for collectors seeking rare artworks: auctions and private sales. Auctions offer transparency, public bidding, and the potential for record-breaking prices, driven by competitive demand and market visibility, though they involve longer timelines and risks such as failure to sell (unsuccessful bids) or underpricing. In contrast, private sales operate behind closed doors, providing privacy, speed, and predictable pricing through confidential negotiations among the seller, buyer, and specialist, making them ideal for high-net-worth individuals, celebrities, and institutions prioritizing discretion. Recent global trends show a significant rise in private sales, with Christie's reporting a 41% increase and Sotheby's a 17% increase in 2024, reaching $15 billion and $14 billion respectively, while auction sales declined. This shift reflects growing demand for privacy, economic uncertainty, and the preferences of new-generation collectors. Despite this, auctions remain vital for gauging market sentiment and enabling dramatic value discoveries. The article concludes that both methods complement each other, offering collectors flexibility and strategic options, with specialized firms like Aurux Vault supporting Korean collectors in navigating global markets. The key to success lies in aligning the chosen method with individual goals and circumstances.

**Art Sales Decline, Luxury Goods Surge: The Big Three Auction Houses Face a Structural Shift**
The 'Big Three' auction houses—Christie's, Sotheby's, and Phillips—are undergoing a strategic shift as luxury goods sales grow rapidly, challenging their traditional identity as art-focused institutions. While fine art sales declined from $10.8 billion in 2022 to $7.04 billion in 2025, luxury category sales rose 18% year-on-year to $1.84 billion in 2025, driven largely by classic cars. Sotheby's now derives about one-third of its revenue from luxury goods—triple the 2019 level—while Christie's luxury segment accounts for roughly one-quarter of total sales. This growth is attributed to rising demand from new wealthy markets, particularly in the Middle East. Experts describe this as a 'structural shift,' with auction houses evolving into integrated luxury platforms offering cars, jewelry, real estate, and high-end consumer goods. While former Christie's CEO Guillaume Cuxat insists this diversification strengthens rather than redefines the auction model, the long-term implications remain uncertain. In South Korea, luxury auctions are still experimental; although Seoul Auction and K Auction have introduced luxury items like Hermès Birkin bags and Rolex watches, fine art remains the dominant revenue source. Notably, 38% of Christie's new customers in 2025 made their first purchase in the luxury category, not art. The trend of declining art sales and rising luxury sales suggests that auction houses may face significant long-term pressure to reconfigure their revenue models and brand identities.

**Booming stock market is fueling a mega-billion return to classic art...**
The classic art market is experiencing a major resurgence, with New York auction houses Christie's, Phillips, and Sotheby's reporting $2.2 billion in sales during the fall season. Despite this, some contemporary works like Maurizio Cattelan’s 'Comedian' (a banana duct-taped to a wall) have seen dramatic appreciation, selling for $6 million in 2024. The broader trend reflects a cultural desire for handmade, spiritually resonant art in an increasingly impersonal digital world, exemplified by the $7.6 million sale of a 15th-century unidentified triptych, 'The Five Miracles of Christ.'

**Unprecedented Record: Rare Gustav Klimt Painting Ignites Global Art Auctions**
A rare painting by Austrian artist Gustav Klimt, titled 'Portrait of Elizabeth Lederer,' sold for $236.4 million at a record-breaking Sotheby's auction in New York, becoming the most expensive artwork ever sold in a public auction and the highest sale in Sotheby's history. The sale, which lasted 20 minutes and drew applause and astonishment from attendees, marked a significant milestone in the global art market. The painting is one of the last remaining portraits of Klimt of such importance, following the 2023 sale of his completed work 'Lady with a Fan' for $108.4 million. Other standout sales included an Edvard Munch painting sold for $35.1 million, a Klimt landscape for $86 million, and a sculpture by Alexander Calder that sold for $889,000—three times its high estimate. The overall collection, led by the Loder Collection, achieved $527.5 million, surpassing its $400 million estimate. Sotheby's recorded a total of $706 million in sales across two auctions, setting a personal record. Notable sales included a Jean-Michel Basquiat work for $48.3 million and a new record for British contemporary artist Cecily Brown at $9.8 million. However, two major works by Kerry James Marshall and Barkley L. Hendricks failed to sell. A controversial golden toilet sculpture by Maurizio Cattelan titled 'America,' weighing 220 pounds and made of 18-karat gold, was offered with a starting bid of $10 million based on its gold value. Only one bid was received—$12.1 million—from Ripley's Believe It or Not!, which operates oddity museums and tourist attractions. The buyer's plans for the piece remain unclear, including whether the public will be allowed to use it. The auction marked the opening of Sotheby's new flagship location near Manhattan’s famed Museum Mile, a strategic move amid a challenging art market. Global art sales declined for the second consecutive year in 2024, with major galleries closing or restructuring, and Sotheby’s, Christie’s, and Phillips reporting an 8% drop in sales compared to the previous year. The event highlighted the contrast between artistic value and material worth, a concept emphasized by David Galbraith, Sotheby’s head of contemporary art, who noted the pricing strategy aimed to spotlight this distinction.

**Auction Aftermath: Bidding Frenzies at Christie's and Sotheby's in London**
Christie's and Sotheby's held successful autumn auctions in London, with Christie's evening sale estimated at £87–129 million and achieving £107 million, selling 83% of lots (four unsold). A Gerhard Richter still life from the 1990s, previously on loan at Vienna’s Belvedere, sold for £6.2 million—nearly double its £3–4 million estimate—just as Richter’s major retrospective opened in Paris. The work was acquired by Art Intelligence Global, founded by Amy Cappellazzo. New records were set for female artists including Paula Rego, Suzanne Valadon, and Annie Morris. Klaus Hegewisch’s collection, previously reported by Handelsblatt on October 2, raised £9 million in its first part, with 72% of lots selling above estimate; however, Picasso’s 'Le repas frugal' (est. £1.5–2.5 million) remained unsold. Sotheby’s smaller auction of 27 lots, expected at £33–48 million, achieved £47.6 million, with 89% sold. Francis Bacon’s 'Portrait of a Dwarf' (est. £6–9 million) was bid for 17 minutes and sold for £13.1 million to Emma Ward of Ward Moretti. Sotheby’s emphasized contemporary art, with no early 20th-century or post-war works, planning to shift such pieces to Paris, where upcoming auctions may exceed €50 million in value. Christie’s remains committed to London for modern art in October, supported by strong results for Post-Impressionist French works. Phillips underperformed with £10.3 million at 82% sell-through. Bonhams is undergoing a transformation, having been acquired by Pemberton Asset Management, with leadership changes underway. Despite differing strategies, both houses are shifting focus toward Paris, where the upcoming Art Basel parallel events are gaining prominence. London’s autumn season avoided disaster, demonstrating that high-quality, rare works continue to ensure strong sales.

**Amid Rocky Mid-Season Sales, Sotheby's Seeks Guarantor for Lauder's $300 Million Klimts**
The art market remains under pressure in the first half of 2025, with auction sales declining 8.8% compared to the same period in 2024, according to the Artnet Intelligence Report. Mid-season auctions at Christie's, Sotheby's, and Phillips saw over 150 unsold lots, including works by major postwar and contemporary artists such as Andy Warhol, Cy Twombly, Frank Stella, KAWS, Jonas Wood, Yayoi Kusama, and Louise Bourgeois. The ultra-contemporary segment (artists born in 1974 or later) contracted by 31.3%, generating $117.2 million, while postwar and contemporary sales fell 12.7% to $1.8 billion. All three houses earned Cs for sell-through rates: Christie's (76% of 294 lots), Phillips (72% of 158 lots), and Sotheby's (70% of 132 lots). A case study on artist Nina Chanel Abney shows her auction results have declined sharply since 2021, with total sales dropping from $2.63 million to $333,684 in 2024. Despite strong institutional support and upcoming museum shows, her works have struggled at auction. Sotheby's is preparing for its most significant test yet: the November 2025 auction of the Leonard Lauder collection, estimated at $400 million, led by three Klimt paintings. Sotheby's has guaranteed the trio and is seeking a third-party guarantor for approximately $300 million to offset risk. The top lot, Portrait of Elisabeth Lederer (1914), is estimated at $150 million; Blumenwiese (1908) at over $80 million; and Waldhag bei Unterach am Attersee (1916) at over $70 million. Potential guarantors include billionaires Ken Griffin, Bernard Arnault, Jeff Bezos, Loraine Powell-Jobs, and Taiwanese tech tycoon Pierre Chen, known for backing Leonardo da Vinci’s Salvator Mundi. Sotheby’s majority owner, Patrick Drahi, is also a possible backer. The auction is seen as 'the Holy Grail' for guarantees. An art advisor noted that while the paintings are exceptional, buyers are cautious and aggressive, making profitability uncertain. The outcome will depend on whether a guarantor can be secured and whether the market responds to such a high-profile, high-value collection.

**Marquee Fall Auctions in Hong Kong Disappoint**
The marquee fall auctions in Hong Kong, jointly staged by Christie's, Sotheby's, and Phillips for the first time in September 2024, failed to meet expectations amid an ongoing downturn in the art market. Despite alignment with Art Basel Hong Kong and positioning as a key event between Frieze Seoul and Shanghai fairs, total sales across all three houses declined compared to the same period last year. Christie's reported HK$565.6 million ($73 million) in sales after fees, down from HK$1.04 billion ($134 million) in the equivalent 2023 sale, with a 92% sell-through rate on 38 lots (35 sold, 3 bought in). The top seller was Pablo Picasso’s 'Buste de femme' (1944), which fetched HK$196.8 million ($25.4 million) after fees—setting a new Asia auction record for the artist. Sotheby's recorded HK$335.7 million ($43 million) in sales, down from HK$409.5 million ($52.6 million) in 2023, with a 65% sell-through rate; its top lot was Yoshitomo Nara’s 'Can't Wait 'til the Night Comes' (2012), selling for HK$79.9 million ($10.3 million). Phillips achieved HK$159.96 million ($20.56 million), down from HK$171.14 million ($21.99 million) in 2023, with a 74% sell-through rate before withdrawals and 100% after; its top lot was Nara’s 'Pinky' (2000), selling for HK$56.66 million ($7.3 million). Notable highlights included Sotheby's setting a new record for London-based Chinese artist Li Hei Di, and Phillips establishing a new record for French artist Jean-Michel Othoniel with 'Black Tornado' (2017), which sold for HK$1.7 million ($215,495). Sotheby's noted that nearly 20% of buyers were new to the house, with seven of the top 10 lots purchased by collectors from Greater China and increased bidding activity from Singapore. Phillips reported that 54% of its lots received early 'priority bids'—a strategy offering a discount on buyer’s premium if bids are submitted at least 48 hours before the sale.
